content.description: Another fun cobble-puller starts up the steep right side of a small pillar then rolls over to easier ground. The last two bolts require sustained crimping with poor feet (more like 10b in my opinion).
content.location: Heads up through the upper right side of the small arch directly in front of the enhanced log bench.  The name and grade are marked on a small rock at the base

content.description: 1st route on left of Cobblestone Wall.

The juggiest route on the wall, and steep for the grade! About 2/3 of the way up, surmount the imposing bulge with big holds then head to the final challenging moves. The last crux is pushing 5.9, though the route has been graded 5.8 in the past.
content.protection: 9 bolts (mostly shiny, couple old and rusty), anchor has fresh rap rings
content.location: The approach trail from Hwy 542 deposits you at the base of this route, where you will find a rounded rock tucked in the ferns, reading "Speaking Spanish (8)". Head up on big holds.

content.description: Long steep line with sustained crimping leading to two cruxes up high.  Relatively clean at the time of posting.
content.location: The is the farthest right line on the main Cobblestone Wall.  From the log bench, a small trail heads about 30 feet right along the base to the start. There is a small rock marked with "Moss Attack (10b)"

content.description: Another fun juggy sport route on central Cobblestone wall.  It starts out vertical, then rolls over a bit to a final sting in the tail.
content.location: Third route from the left, immediately right of Cabo. It goes up through the left side of the small arch. Presently, it has older bolts and more moss but climbs OK if dry

content.description: 2nd route from the left end of the crag. Currently has a small plaque at the bottom of the route with the route name and grade.
